author: afdudley
content: How close is Ropsten to mainnet?

author: afdudley
content: It's the only PoW testnet, right?

author: sky.cactus
content: <@332923501079953409> It is the only public PoW test network that all of the clients actively target/support that I know of.

author: abdel.stark
content:
> Yeah Abdel, he mentioned he made a comment on Ian‚Äôs Geth PR.
<@!187490121698770945> Ian answered. Actually it was not a bug but more an issue in the spec. https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/20618#discussion_r397536677

author: afdudley
content: As one of the authors of the spec and the person that hired Ian, at the moment the code is canonical, not the spec.

author: afdudley
content: There are known issues with the mechanisms and the spec, we decided to provide an implementation anyway since that's all we could get feedback on.

author: timbeiko
content: Cool. We're happy to help feed back changes in the spec as we do our implementation as well.

author: afdudley
content:
I don't think that we will discover the issues from implementation because it's a change in mechanism more than a change in architecture. Or put another way, the change that we are most concerned with is in agent behavior, not in code behavior.

The reason the spec isn't finalized is because it seems unlikely that it has the expected level of safety from a mechanism perspective.

author: afdudley
content: I'm happy for you folks to make an implementation, but that strictly speaking doesn't get us any closer to knowing if the code changes _force_ the change in behavior we are expecting. Ropsten won't demonstrate that either.

author: afdudley
content: It appears to me that people are fine going to mainnet knowing all of the above, which again is fine with me, I just want to be as clear as possible regarding my personal view.

author: .vbuterin
content: yeah the reason I am pushing for ropsten is that that's the closest we may get to realistic patterns of usage

author: .vbuterin
content: It's nowhere near as good as mainnet itself of course

author: .vbuterin
content: But you are completely right that the expected benefits of the proposal, and the risks, are all behavioral, not technical, so we learn less from a pure tech implementation than we would for a usual EIP

author: trent_vanepps
content: I think agent simulation should be a prerequisite for activation. I know Gauntlet has signalled interest in the past. <@!187490121698770945> might be working to restart conversation with them?

author: madeof_tin7509
content: I haven‚Äôt, is that something you would like to do? <@420951281910284289>

author: madeof_tin7509
content: There is someone at the EF working on the mechanism design. I am not sure he is in this channel, but I can ask him to join it.

author: afdudley
content: We had no money to pay Gauntlet, I think that issue remains.

author: afdudley
content: If we want to do a free/community driven agent-based model, that's fine, but it will take at least 6 months, i don't think people want to wait for that. If the community decides to do it Bill O'Reilly Style, I'll accept that, but me actually wanting agent modeling is what slowed this down.

author: afdudley
content: I gave up on that path.

author: trent_vanepps
content: <@!187490121698770945> I am fulltime with ETHGlobal, I have less time to dedicate to these things now. but I will try to stay up to date

author: madeof_tin7509
content: We talked earlier about molochDAO having a proposal to fund something like agent based. Without funds for it I don‚Äôt see value in restarting the conversation with gauntlet.

author: madeof_tin7509
content:
> I think agent simulation should be a prerequisite for activation.

This would be nice. But, simply stating that it is isn‚Äôt going to get us anywhere without some proposals/funding for them.

author: kiwi.eth
content: What does agent simulation entail? Not familiar with the term

author: madeof_tin7509
content: There is an okayish wikepieda article on this: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model

author: madeof_tin7509
content: But in our case it is making agents (miners, users making transactions) and then simulating what they would do in a scenario.

author: kiwi.eth
content: Ahhh so it's a simulation that includes the simulation of its participants?

author: kiwi.eth
content: Not just the functionality alone?

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Yes

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Economics is hard because participants can act in weird ways and have unintended effects.

author: kiwi.eth
content: Got it, thank you. I have some time and was considering building out a simple simulation but I intended it to something much simpler, not sure if that would be beneficial

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Would love to hear more about what you were thinking, cause we could use all the help we can get üòÜ

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Simpler is good too üëç

author: kiwi.eth
content: I'd have to plot it out but was thinking of making something that would start with a TX pool of sorts and model or simulate how the blocks would handle them and react

author: kiwi.eth
content: Like if the tx pool is say, 50 TXs, with these certain gas prices and such, to do a simple simulation of how the block would take it, how the base fee would change, how the next block would look, etc. I'd have to think it out more but if that sounds like something beneficial I can probably make time to get started at least

author: kiwi.eth
content: Maybe we could even work off of it to add agents, wdyt

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Sounds very promising to me üëè

author: kiwi.eth
content: (would be in golang)

author: madeof_tin7509
content: feeding the pool transactions and then simulating what would happen sounds like a great starting place.

author: kiwi.eth
content: Great! I'll get started on a design doc soon then, plenty of time with this quarantine stuff thankfully haha

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Use Ian‚Äôs PR as a reference when you are building the model <@!118185622543269890> it is also in Golang so that is nice. üòÅ

author: kiwi.eth
content: Will do! I already took a few glances over it, it'll definitely be helpful, thanks!

author: afdudley
content: Are you going to write your txpool in go as well?

author: afdudley
content: It makes sense to just take the geth code and write a simulator that plugs directly into those modules, if that's what you're thinking.

author: kiwi.eth
content: Yeah, although it wont be very complex, just the minimum structure needed to handle gas costs

author: kiwi.eth
content: But I'll definitely consider using what geth has

author: kiwi.eth
content: Thanks, might be a good idea üôÇ

content: I don't understand geth well enough to see if I wanna use it so I'll do some digging tonight
